The Global Positioning System (GPS) is a satellite-based navigation system, which allows users to determine their precise location and track movement across the Earth. It uses signals transmitted by GPS satellites, allowing our smartphones or other devices to calculate their exact position on the planet.

The global positioning system was developed in 1973 by the United States Department of Defense and became fully operational in 1995. Initially, it was created for military purposes but later opened up for civilian use after a presidential order issued in 1983. Nowadays, GPS plays an essential role in various industries such as transportation, agriculture, emergency services and smartphone technology.

Accuracy may vary depending on several factors including atmospheric conditions and signal blockage due to buildings or trees. However, advanced technologies like Assisted-GPS have been developed to overcome these issues while further enhancing accuracy levels down to around three meters or less under optimal circumstances.

To use GPS effectively:

1. Ensure that you have a device with built-in GPS capability: Most modern smartphones are equipped with this feature.
2. Enable Location Services/GPS on your device: Look through your device settings menu for location-related options; often found under "Privacy" or "Security."
3. Check if your phone has the necessary software applications installed: Downloading apps specifically designed for navigating should help maximize efficiency—Google Maps being an excellent example—especially when traveling unknown territory.
